households.kinship¶

Kinship functions for analyzing birth and marriage relationships.

The kinship module uses the relationship network and a focal person to identify relationships such as spouses, children, parents, and nuclear families. By providing a basic definition of children and parents in particular, it enables more complex queries into cousins of varying degrees.

While in a given implementation the Person objects may have easy-to-use variables for parents, spouses, and children, in general it is preferred to use the kinship functions for accessing these variables.

A future extension will be to add kinship setter functions.

See Also¶

residency

The module that analyzes kinship as it relates to residency, e.g. co-residential household structure.

kinship.get_spouse(person)¶

Return the spouse of a person; otherwise return None.

personPerson

The person in question.

Person or None

Returns the spouse of the person, otherwise returns None.

kinship.get_parents(person)¶

Return the parents of an individual; otherwise return empty list.

personPerson

The Person in question.

{[Person, Person], []}

Returns a list with the parents of the person, otherwise returns empty list.

kinship.get_children(person)¶

Return the children of an individual; otherwise return empty list.

personPerson

The Person in question.

{[Person,], None}

Returns a list with the children of the person, otherwise returns None.

kinship.get_siblings(person)¶

Return the siblings of an individual; otherwise, return None.

personPerson

The Person in question.

{[Person,], None}

Returns a list with the siblings of the person, otherwise returns None.

kinship.get_family(person)¶

Return a person’s nuclear family (spouse and children) including themselves.

personPerson

The Person in question.

[Person,]

Returns a list with the nuclear family of the person, otherwise returns None.
